ChatGPT said:

The issue with your extension not highlighting keywords in Gmail could be due to a few reasons:

Possible Issues:

  1. Gmail’s Dynamic Content Loading

    • Gmail loads emails dynamically, meaning elements may not be immediately available when content.js runs. The MutationObserver you implemented (observeGmailChanges()) should help, but it might not be triggering properly.

  2. Incorrect Element Selection

    • The script targets elements with div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, but Gmail’s DOM structure may differ when viewing an email compared to the inbox.

  3. InnerHTML Replacement Issues

    • The current method of replacing keywords (el.innerHTML.replace(regex, ... )) may not be consistently applied if Gmail modifies the content dynamically.

  4. Insufficient Permissions

    • manifest.json includes host_permissions for Gmail, but it may need additional permissions for scripting execution.

Suggested Fixes:

1️⃣ Modify Element Selection for Email Body

Change how emailElements are selected to ensure both inbox and opened emails are scanned. Update this part in content.js:

js
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        // Select email content dynamically
        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt"); 

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            let textContent = el.textContent || el.innerText;

            if (textContent.trim() === "") {
                return;
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");
                if (regex.test(textContent)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, textContent);
                    el.innerHTML = el.innerHTML.replace(regex, `<span class="highlight">$&</span>`);
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

🔹 Fixes:

  • Adds .ii.gt, which is Gmail’s internal class for opened emails.

  • Ensures keywords are detected both in the inbox preview and in the opened email.

2️⃣ Ensure Observer Runs Continuously

Modify observeGmailChanges() to handle Gmail’s constant DOM updates:

js
function observeGmailChanges() {
    const observer = new MutationObserver((mutations) => {
        debounce(() => scanEmailContent(), 1000); // Reduce debounce time for quicker response
    });

    observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true, characterData: true });
}

🔹 Fixes:

  • Watches for changes in characterData too, in case Gmail updates content dynamically.

3️⃣ Modify Manifest Permissions

In manifest.json, add tabs permission to ensure Gmail allows content scripts to run properly:

json
"permissions": [
  "storage",
  "activeTab",
  "scripting",
  "tabs"
]

🔹 Fixes:

  • Ensures Gmail allows content scripts to interact properly.

🔥 Final Steps:

  1. Update content.js and manifest.json as described.

  2. Reload the extension in Chrome:

    • Go to chrome://extensions/

    • Enable Developer Mode

    • Click Reload

  3. Test in Gmail:

    • Open Gmail and check if keywords are highlighted both in the inbox and inside emails.

This should resolve the issue and ensure phishing keywords are correctly highlighted in all Gmail views. 🚀

ChatGPT said:

Here is the updated full code for your extension with the necessary fixes to ensure phishing keywords are properly highlighted in both the inbox and when viewing an email in Gmail.

📌 Updated content.js

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

// Function to debounce the scanning to prevent overwhelming Gmail
let debounceTimer;
function debounce(func, delay) {
    clearTimeout(debounceTimer);
    debounceTimer = setTimeout(func, delay);
}

// Function to highlight phishing keywords in email content
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        // Target Gmail text areas for both inbox and opened emails
        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            let textContent = el.textContent || el.innerText; // Get the text content

            if (textContent.trim() === "") {
                return; // Skip empty text nodes
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                // Use regex to match phishing keywords with case insensitivity and word boundaries
                let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

                // Check if keyword is found
                if (regex.test(textContent)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, textContent);

                    // Wrap matched keyword with a span tag for highlighting
                    el.innerHTML = el.innerHTML.replace(regex, `<span class="highlight">$&</span>`);
                }
            });
        });
    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

// Observe Gmail changes for dynamically loaded content
function observeGmailChanges() {
    const observer = new MutationObserver(() => {
        debounce(() => scanEmailContent(), 1000); // Reduce debounce time for quicker response
    });

    observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true, characterData: true });
}

// Wait for Gmail to fully load before starting the script
window.addEventListener('load', function () {
    setTimeout(() => {
        scanEmailContent();  // Initial scan of the content
        observeGmailChanges();  // Start observing for changes
    }, 3000); // 3 seconds delay to allow Gmail to load completely
});

📌 Updated background.js

javascript
chrome.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {
    if (message.action === "checkLinks") {
        const suspiciousPatterns = ["bit.ly", "tinyurl", "free-gift", "bank-update", "paypal-security"];
        let flaggedLinks = [];

        message.links.forEach((link) => {
            suspiciousPatterns.forEach((pattern) => {
                if (link.includes(pattern)) {
                    flaggedLinks.push(link);
                }
            });
        });

        sendResponse({ flaggedLinks });
    }
});

📌 Updated popup.js

javascript
document.getElementById("scanEmails").addEventListener("click", () => {
    alert("Scanning emails for phishing threats...");
});

document.getElementById("scanLinks").addEventListener("click", () => {
    chrome.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }, (tabs) => {
        chrome.scripting.executeScript({
            target: { tabId: tabs[0].id },
            function: detectPhishingLinks
        });
    });
});

function detectPhishingLinks() {
    const links = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll("a")).map(a => a.href);
    chrome.runtime.sendMessage({ action: "checkLinks", links }, (response) => {
        const alertList = document.getElementById("alertList");
        alertList.innerHTML = "";

        if (response.flaggedLinks.length > 0) {
            response.flaggedLinks.forEach(link => {
                let listItem = document.createElement("li");
                listItem.textContent = `⚠️ Suspicious link: ${link}`;
                alertList.appendChild(listItem);
            });
        } else {
            alert("No suspicious links found.");
        }
    });
}

📝 Updated scanEmailContent() in content.js
javascript
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        // Select elements containing email content
        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            let textContent = el.innerHTML || el.innerText; // Use innerHTML to modify content

            if (textContent.trim() === "") {
                return; // Skip empty text nodes
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

                if (regex.test(textContent)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, textContent);

                    // Apply highlighting safely by wrapping the word in a span
                    el.innerHTML = textContent.replace(regex, (match) => {
                        return `<span class="highlight">${match}</span>`;
                    });
                }
            });
        });
    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

🔥 Why This Fix Works

  1. Uses innerHTML.replace() correctly

    • Ensures the modification works even if Gmail dynamically loads content.

  2. Wraps matched keywords in a <span>

    • Ensures the CSS .highlight style is applied.

🔧 Fix: Prevent Nested Highlights

We need to modify content.js so that the script does not repeatedly wrap already-highlighted text.

📌 Updated scanEmailContent()

javascript
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        // Select elements containing email content
        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            let textContent = el.innerHTML;

            if (textContent.trim() === "") {
                return; // Skip empty text nodes
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

                // Prevent wrapping an already-highlighted keyword
                if (!el.innerHTML.includes('class="highlight"')) {
                    el.innerHTML = textContent.replace(regex, (match) => {
                        return `<span class="highlight">${match}</span>`;
                    });
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

🔥 Why This Fix Works

✔ Prevents multiple highlights by checking if <span class="highlight"> is already present.
✔ Ensures Gmail content remains readable without excessive nesting.

  2. Reload the extension in chrome://extensions/.

🔧 Final Fix: Ensure HTML Modification Works

🛠 Issue: Gmail Uses innerText Instead of innerHTML in Some Places

Gmail dynamically updates its content, and using innerHTML.replace() may not be enough. Instead, we should modify the child nodes of elements directly.

📌 Final Fix in content.js

Replace your existing scanEmailContent() function with this updated version:

javascript
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        // Select elements containing email content
        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            let textContent = el.innerText;  // Use innerText to get raw text without HTML

            if (textContent.trim() === "") {
                return; // Skip empty text nodes
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

                if (regex.test(textContent)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, textContent);

                    // Replace text content while preserving Gmail structure
                    let highlightedText = textContent.replace(regex, (match) => {
                        return `<span class="highlight">${match}</span>`;
                    });

                    let newElement = document.createElement("span");
                    newElement.innerHTML = highlightedText;
                    el.replaceWith(newElement);
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

✅ Why This Fix Works

✔ Uses innerText instead of innerHTML for safer text extraction.
✔ Creates a new <span> element to replace the original text without breaking Gmail’s structure.
✔ Prevents double-wrapping <span> elements in existing text.

🚀 Final Steps

  1. Update content.js with the new function.

  2. Reload the extension in chrome://extensions/ and refresh Gmail.

  3. Check if phishing keywords are now highlighted!

🔹 This should finally make the phishing keywords visible in Gmail! 🚀 Let me know if it works now. 😊

ChatGPT said:

Since the extension detects phishing keywords (as confirmed by the console logs) but does not visibly highlight them in Gmail, it seems like Gmail's DOM structure is interfering with innerHTML modifications.

🛠 Fix: Ensure Highlighting Works Properly in Gmail

Instead of replacing the text content with innerHTML, we will directly modify the DOM nodes by:

  1. Checking if a word is already highlighted

  2. Splitting text nodes and inserting <span class="highlight"> manually

  3. Ensuring Gmail does not overwrite our changes

📌 Final Fix: Update content.js

Replace your current scanEmailContent() function with this new version:

javascript
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            if (!el || el.innerHTML.includes('class="highlight"')) {
                return; // Skip already highlighted elements
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

                if (regex.test(el.innerText)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, el.innerText);

                    // Replace text safely without breaking Gmail's structure
                    highlightKeyword(el, keyword);
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

// Function to wrap phishing keywords with <span class="highlight">
function highlightKeyword(element, keyword) {
    let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

    function replaceTextWithHighlight(node) {
        if (node.nodeType === 3) { // Text node
            let match = node.nodeValue.match(regex);
            if (match) {
                let span = document.createElement("span");
                span.innerHTML = node.nodeValue.replace(regex, `<span class="highlight">${match[0]}</span>`);
                node.replaceWith(span);
            }
        } else if (node.nodeType === 1) { // Element node
            node.childNodes.forEach(replaceTextWithHighlight);
        }
    }

    replaceTextWithHighlight(element);
}

// Observe Gmail for dynamic updates
function observeGmailChanges() {
    const observer = new MutationObserver(() => {
        scanEmailContent();
    });

    observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });
}

// Start scanning when Gmail loads
window.addEventListener('load', function () {
    setTimeout(() => {
        scanEmailContent();  
        observeGmailChanges();
    }, 3000); // Give Gmail time to fully load
});

✅ Why This Fix Works

✔ Uses nodeValue instead of innerHTML, preventing Gmail from interfering.
✔ Does not re-highlight already modified text, preventing duplicates.
✔ Directly modifies the text nodes, ensuring Gmail does not override changes.
✔ Uses a MutationObserver to detect Gmail's dynamic content updates.

🚀 Final Steps

  1. Update content.js with the new function above.

  2. Reload the extension (chrome://extensions/ → Click Reload).

  3. Refresh Gmail and check if phishing keywords are now highlighted.

🔹 This method directly modifies Gmail’s text without disrupting its structure. Let me know if it finally works! 🚀😊

function injectStyles() {
    let style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .highlight {
            background-color: yellow !important;
            font-weight: bold !important;
            color: red !important;
            border-radius: 2px !important;
            padding: 2px !important;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

injectStyles(); // Apply styles as soon as the script runs

✅ 2. Ensure !important is Applied Properly

Gmail sometimes overrides styles. Try modifying the CSS:

css
/* Stronger highlighting enforcement */
.highlight {
    background-color: yellow !important;
    font-weight: bold !important;
    color: red !important;
    border-radius: 3px !important;
    padding: 2px !important;
    display: inline !important;
}

✅ 3. Check if Styles are Overridden

  1. Right-click a highlighted word in Gmail.

  3. Look for .highlight in the Styles panel.

🔥 Issue: Gmail Freezing Due to High Processing Load

✅ Optimized Fix: Reduce Processing Load

Instead of scanning every element on every change, we will:

  1. Limit the number of elements scanned per cycle.

  2. Use a MutationObserver efficiently to detect changes.

  3. Throttle the scanning process to avoid overloading Gmail.

📌 New Optimized content.js

Replace your current content.js with this optimized version:

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

// Debounce function to reduce excessive processing
let debounceTimer;
function debounce(func, delay) {
    clearTimeout(debounceTimer);
    debounceTimer = setTimeout(func, delay);
}

// Function to safely highlight keywords
function highlightKeyword(element, keyword) {
    let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

    function processTextNodes(node) {
        if (node.nodeType === 3) { // Text node
            let match = node.nodeValue.match(regex);
            if (match) {
                let span = document.createElement("span");
                span.innerHTML = node.nodeValue.replace(regex, `<span class="highlight">${match[0]}</span>`);
                node.replaceWith(span);
            }
        } else if (node.nodeType === 1) { // Element node
            node.childNodes.forEach(processTextNodes);
        }
    }

    processTextNodes(element);
}

// Function to scan and highlight keywords efficiently
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements = Array.from(emailElements).slice(0, 100); // LIMIT SCANNING TO 100 ELEMENTS

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            if (!el || el.innerHTML.includes('class="highlight"')) {
                return; // Skip already highlighted elements
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                if (new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi").test(el.innerText)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, el.innerText);
                    highlightKeyword(el, keyword);
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

// Observe Gmail for dynamic updates (optimized)
function observeGmailChanges() {
    const observer = new MutationObserver(() => {
        debounce(() => scanEmailContent(), 2000); // Throttle scanning to every 2 seconds
    });

    observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });
}

// Inject necessary styles
function injectStyles() {
    let style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .highlight {
            background-color: yellow !important;
            font-weight: bold !important;
            color: red !important;
            border-radius: 2px !important;
            padding: 2px !important;
            display: inline !important;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

// Initialize scanning when Gmail loads
window.addEventListener('load', function () {
    setTimeout(() => {
        injectStyles();
        scanEmailContent();  
        observeGmailChanges();
    }, 3000); // Give Gmail time to fully load
});

🚀 Why This Fix Works

✔ Limits processing to 100 elements per scan to prevent lag.
✔ Uses debounce() to avoid overwhelming Gmail with frequent scanning.
✔ Efficiently watches for Gmail updates using MutationObserver.
✔ Injects CSS dynamically, ensuring styles apply even if Gmail resets them.

✅ Final Steps

  1. Replace content.js with the optimized version above.

  2. Reload the extension in chrome://extensions/ (click Reload).

  3. Refresh Gmail and check for keyword highlighting.

🔥 Expected Outcome

✅ Gmail remains responsive (no freezing).
✅ Keywords are highlighted properly.
✅ No performance issues due to optimized scanning.

✅ New Approach: Use contentEditable Workaround

Instead of modifying innerText or innerHTML directly (which Gmail might block), we will:

  • Clone the text node, modify it, and replace the original.

  • Use contentEditable to allow modifications.

  • Ensure Gmail’s JavaScript does not revert changes.

📌 Updated content.js

Replace your existing content.js with this new version:

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

// Function to safely highlight keywords
function highlightKeyword(element, keyword) {
    let regex = new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi");

    function processTextNodes(node) {
        if (node.nodeType === 3) { // Text node
            let match = node.nodeValue.match(regex);
            if (match) {
                let span = document.createElement("span");
                span.classList.add("highlight");
                span.textContent = match[0];
                let newNode = node.splitText(node.nodeValue.indexOf(match[0]));
                newNode.nodeValue = newNode.nodeValue.substring(match[0].length);
                node.after(span);
            }
        } else if (node.nodeType === 1) { // Element node
            node.childNodes.forEach(processTextNodes);
        }
    }

    processTextNodes(element);
}

// Function to scan and highlight keywords efficiently
function scanEmailContent() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail emails for phishing threats...");

        let emailElements = document.querySelectorAll("div[role='article'], div[role='listitem'], span, .ii.gt");

        emailElements = Array.from(emailElements).slice(0, 100); // LIMIT SCANNING TO 100 ELEMENTS

        emailElements.forEach((el) => {
            if (!el || el.innerHTML.includes('class="highlight"')) {
                return; // Skip already highlighted elements
            }

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                if (new RegExp(`\\b${keyword}\\b`, "gi").test(el.innerText)) {
                    console.log(`Found keyword: "${keyword}" in text:`, el.innerText);
                    highlightKeyword(el, keyword);
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error during phishing scan:", error);
    }
}

// Observe Gmail for dynamic updates
function observeGmailChanges() {
    const observer = new MutationObserver(() => {
        scanEmailContent();
    });

    observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });
}

// Inject necessary styles
function injectStyles() {
    let style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .highlight {
            background-color: yellow !important;
            font-weight: bold !important;
            color: red !important;
            border-radius: 2px !important;
            padding: 2px !important;
            display: inline !important;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

// Enable content editing to allow DOM modifications
function enableEditing() {
    document.body.contentEditable = true;
}

// Initialize scanning when Gmail loads
window.addEventListener('load', function () {
    setTimeout(() => {
        enableEditing();
        injectStyles();
        scanEmailContent();
        observeGmailChanges();
    }, 3000); // Give Gmail time to fully load
});

✅ New Approach: Highlight the Email Row Instead

Instead of modifying innerHTML, we will:

  • Find the email row (tr) that contains a phishing keyword.

  • Apply a background color to the entire row.

📌 New Optimized content.js

Replace your existing content.js with this new version:

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

// Function to highlight entire email row
function highlightEmailRow(row) {
    row.classList.add("phishing-alert");
}

// Function to scan and highlight Gmail inbox rows
function scanGmailInbox() {
    try {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail inbox for phishing threats...");

        // Select all email rows in Gmail
        let emailRows = document.querySelectorAll("tr"); // Gmail uses <tr> for email rows

        emailRows.forEach((row) => {
            if (row.classList.contains("phishing-alert")) {
                return; // Skip if already highlighted
            }

            let emailText = row.innerText.toLowerCase(); // Get text inside row

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                if (emailText.includes(keyword.toLowerCase())) {
                    console.log(`Phishing keyword detected: "${keyword}" in email.`);
                    highlightEmailRow(row);
                }
            });
        });

    } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error scanning Gmail inbox:", error);
    }
}

// Observe Gmail for dynamic updates (optimized)
function observeGmailChanges() {
    const observer = new MutationObserver(() => {
        scanGmailInbox();
    });

    observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });
}

// Inject styles to highlight entire row
function injectStyles() {
    let style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .phishing-alert {
            background-color: #ffcccc !important; /* Light red background */
            font-weight: bold !important;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

// Initialize scanning when Gmail loads
window.addEventListener("load", function () {
    setTimeout(() => {
        injectStyles();
        scanGmailInbox();
        observeGmailChanges();
    }, 3000); // Wait for Gmail to load fully
});

🚀 Why This Fix Works

✔ Targets the entire email row (tr) instead of modifying Gmail’s complex internal structure.
✔ Ensures Gmail does not reset styles using a CSS class (.phishing-alert).
✔ Uses MutationObserver to detect new emails dynamically.
✔ Prevents reprocessing rows that are already highlighted to improve performance.

✅ Final Steps

  2. Reload the extension in chrome://extensions/ (click Reload).

  3. Refresh Gmail and check if phishing emails now have a red background.

📌 Fixed popup.js

Replace your existing popup.js with this version:

javascript
document.getElementById("scanEmails").addEventListener("click", () => {
    chrome.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }, (tabs) => {
        if (tabs.length === 0) return; // Ensure there's an active tab
        chrome.tabs.sendMessage(tabs[0].id, { action: "scanEmails" }, (response) => {
            if (chrome.runtime.lastError) {
                console.error("Error sending message:", chrome.runtime.lastError.message);
            } else {
                console.log("Scan triggered:", response?.status || "No response");
            }
        });
    });
});

🔹 Fixes:

  • Uses chrome.tabs.sendMessage() instead of chrome.scripting.executeScript().

  • Checks if there's an active tab before sending the message.

  • Logs errors if the message fails to send.

📌 Updated content.js (Toggle Highlighting)

Replace your current content.js with this version:

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

let isHighlighting = false; // Flag to track state

// Function to highlight entire email row
function highlightEmailRow(row) {
    row.classList.add("phishing-alert");
}

// Function to remove highlighting from all rows
function removeHighlights() {
    let highlightedRows = document.querySelectorAll(".phishing-alert");
    highlightedRows.forEach(row => row.classList.remove("phishing-alert"));
}

// Function to scan and highlight Gmail inbox rows
function scanGmailInbox() {
    if (isHighlighting) {
        console.log("Disabling highlighting...");
        removeHighlights();
        isHighlighting = false;
    } else {
        console.log("Scanning Gmail inbox for phishing threats...");

        let emailRows = document.querySelectorAll("tr");

        emailRows.forEach((row) => {
            if (row.classList.contains("phishing-alert")) {
                return; // Skip already highlighted rows
            }

            let emailText = row.innerText.toLowerCase();

            phishingKeywords.forEach((keyword) => {
                if (emailText.includes(keyword.toLowerCase())) {
                    console.log(`Phishing keyword detected: "${keyword}" in email.`);
                    highlightEmailRow(row);
                }
            });
        });

        isHighlighting = true;
    }
}

// Inject styles to highlight entire row
function injectStyles() {
    let style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .phishing-alert {
            background-color: #ffcccc !important;
            font-weight: bold !important;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

    if (message.action === "toggleScanEmails") {
        scanGmailInbox(); // Toggle highlighting
        sendResponse({ status: isHighlighting ? "Highlighting enabled" : "Highlighting disabled" });
    }

javascript
document.getElementById("scanEmails").addEventListener("click", () => {
    chrome.tabs.query({ active: true, currentWindow: true }, (tabs) => {
        if (tabs.length === 0) return;
        chrome.tabs.sendMessage(tabs[0].id, { action: "toggleScanEmails" }, (response) => {
            if (chrome.runtime.lastError) {
                console.error("Error sending message:", chrome.runtime.lastError.message);
            } else {
                console.log("Toggled scan:", response?.status || "No response");
                updateButton(response?.status);
            }
        });
    });
});

// Function to update button text
function updateButton(status) {
    let button = document.getElementById("scanEmails");
    if (status === "Highlighting enabled") {
        button.textContent = "Stop Highlighting";
    } else {
        button.textContent = "Scan Emails";
    }
}

The extension implements a basic rule-based keyword filtering method to detect potential phishing emails.

✅ Filtering Method Used: Keyword Matching (Rule-Based Filter)

The extension scans the content of emails using a predefined list of suspicious keywords, such as:

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
  "urgent",
  "verify your account",
  "password reset",
  "suspicious activity",
  "update your details",
  "click here",
  "confirm now",
  "free gift",
  "bank account",
  "security alert",
  "confirm here"
];

🔍 How It Works

  1. When you click "Scan Emails", the script:

    • Loops through visible email rows (<tr> elements in Gmail).

    • Converts the text content to lowercase.

    • Compares it against each keyword in the list using:

      javascript
      emailText.includes(keyword.toLowerCase())

  2. If a match is found:

    • The email row is highlighted in red (indicating a phishing alert).

🎯 Type of Filtering Technique

This falls under:

  • ✅ Rule-Based Filtering

  • ✅ Static Keyword Matching

  • ❌ Not AI-based

  • ❌ Not dynamic or context-aware

⚖️ Pros

  • ✅ Simple and fast

  • ✅ Easy to control and update

  • ✅ Works offline (no API or ML model needed)

⚠️ Limitations

  • ❌ Might miss cleverly disguised phishing emails (e.g., "verify ur account" instead of "verify your account")

  • ❌ Can generate false positives

  • ❌ Does not adapt to new phishing trends

🧠 Want to Go Further?

ChatGPT said:

The extension uses a rule-based keyword filtering method to detect potential phishing emails within the Gmail interface. This approach involves a predefined list of common phishing-related phrases such as "verify your account," "password reset," and "security alert." When the user clicks the "Scan Emails" button in the extension popup, the script scans the visible email rows in Gmail’s inbox and checks if any of these keywords are present within the text content of each row. If a match is found, the corresponding email row is visually highlighted with a red background to alert the user. This keyword detection is case-insensitive and relies on direct string comparison using JavaScript’s includes() method. The highlighting can be toggled on and off by clicking the same button again, providing the user control over when to enable or disable phishing detection. While this method is simple and effective for detecting obvious threats, it does not use machine learning or contextual analysis, and therefore may not identify more subtle or obfuscated phishing attempts.

You said:
Is it possible to combine both rule-based and Bayesian Filtering together while building the extension?
ChatGPT said:

Yes, it’s absolutely possible to combine rule-based filtering and Bayesian filtering in a browser extension like yours — and doing so can significantly improve phishing detection accuracy.

✅ How You Can Combine Rule-Based and Bayesian Filtering

1. Rule-Based Filtering (already implemented):

This uses a list of suspicious keywords or URL patterns to instantly flag known phishing traits. It's fast and easy to maintain, but limited in flexibility.

2. Bayesian Filtering (what you'd add):

This uses probability theory to calculate the likelihood that an email is phishing based on the words it contains — even if those words aren't explicitly in your keyword list.

🧠 How They Work Together

You can design the extension to:

  1. Run the rule-based filter first.

    • Highlight anything that obviously matches known keywords (like "verify your account").

  2. Then, pass the same email content into a Bayesian classifier.

    • This classifier is trained on example phishing and non-phishing emails.

    • It evaluates word probabilities and returns a score — for example, "This message has a 78% chance of being phishing."

  3. Combine both results to decide:

    • If either the rule-based or Bayesian result exceeds a threshold (e.g., keyword match or >70% probability), mark it as suspicious.

🛠️ Is It Practical in a Chrome Extension?

Yes, but there are some considerations:

  • A JavaScript-based Bayesian classifier (like bayes.js) can run in the browser without server calls.

  • You’ll need a pretrained model or to let the extension train on example data (you can store this locally using chrome.storage).

  • You'll also need to tokenize and preprocess email content cleanly — and manage performance.

✅ Benefits of Combining Both

  • 🔍 Catches both obvious and subtle threats

  • 📈 Improves accuracy and reduces false positives

  • 🧠 Adapts to new phishing tricks if trained continuously

🧪 Want an Example?

I can provide a sample of how to integrate a lightweight Bayesian classifier in your content script and combine it with your current keyword logic.

ChatGPT said:

Awesome — since you’ve already got a solid rule-based detection system in place, I’ll now show you how to integrate Bayesian filtering into your Gmail phishing extension, combining both methods intelligently.

✅ Implementation Plan

We'll use:

  • ✅ Rule-based detection (your current keyword matching)

  • ✅ A lightweight Naive Bayesian classifier (trained on example phishing vs. legit words)

📦 Step-by-Step Integration

✅ 1. Add a Simple Bayesian Classifier

We'll define a Bayesian classifier directly in content.js with training examples.

✅ 2. Combine Rule-Based and Bayesian Results

Highlight an email row if either:

  • A phishing keyword is matched (rule-based), or

  • The Bayesian classifier says it’s likely phishing (e.g., ≥ 0.7)

📌 Updated content.js (combined rule-based + Bayesian filtering)

Replace your content.js with this version:

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

let isHighlighting = false;

// Bayesian classifier implementation
class NaiveBayes {
    constructor() {
        this.spam = {};
        this.ham = {};
        this.spamCount = 0;
        this.hamCount = 0;
    }

    train(text, label) {
        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        const dict = label === "spam" ? this.spam : this.ham;
        if (label === "spam") this.spamCount++;
        else this.hamCount++;

        words.forEach(word => {
            dict[word] = (dict[word] || 0) + 1;
        });
    }

    predict(text) {
        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount));
        let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount));

        words.forEach(word => {
            spamScore += Math.log((this.spam[word] || 1) / this.spamCount);
            hamScore += Math.log((this.ham[word] || 1) / this.hamCount);
        });

        const spamProb = 1 / (1 + Math.exp(hamScore - spamScore));
        return spamProb; // Returns probability it's phishing
    }
}

// Instantiate and train classifier
const classifier = new NaiveBayes();

// Sample training data
classifier.train("urgent verify account reset click free gift", "spam");
classifier.train("your package has shipped see you soon", "ham");
classifier.train("password reset confirm now", "spam");
classifier.train("meeting agenda update project", "ham");

// Highlight row
function highlightEmailRow(row) {
    row.classList.add("phishing-alert");
}

// Remove highlights
function removeHighlights() {
    let highlightedRows = document.querySelectorAll(".phishing-alert");
    highlightedRows.forEach(row => row.classList.remove("phishing-alert"));
}

// Scan using both rule-based and Bayesian logic
function scanGmailInbox() {
    if (isHighlighting) {
        console.log("Removing highlights...");
        removeHighlights();
        isHighlighting = false;
        return;
    }

    console.log("Scanning Gmail inbox for phishing threats...");

    const emailRows = document.querySelectorAll("tr");

    emailRows.forEach((row) => {
        if (!row || row.classList.contains("phishing-alert")) return;

        const emailText = row.innerText.toLowerCase();

        // Rule-based check
        const matchedKeyword = phishingKeywords.some(kw => emailText.includes(kw));

        // Bayesian check
        const phishingProb = classifier.predict(emailText);
        const isPhishy = phishingProb >= 0.7;

        if (matchedKeyword || isPhishy) {
            console.log(`Phishing detected: ${matchedKeyword ? 'Rule-based' : 'Bayesian'} | Prob=${phishingProb.toFixed(2)}`);
            highlightEmailRow(row);
        }
    });

    isHighlighting = true;
}

// Inject styles
function injectStyles() {
    let style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .phishing-alert {
            background-color: #ffcccc !important;
            font-weight: bold !important;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

// Listen for scan toggle
chrome.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {
    if (message.action === "scanEmails") {
        scanGmailInbox();
        sendResponse({ status: isHighlighting ? "Highlighting enabled" : "Highlighting disabled" });
    }
});

injectStyles();

✅ Summary for Your Professor

This extension combines rule-based filtering with a lightweight Naive Bayesian classifier to enhance phishing email detection. The rule-based system flags emails with known phishing phrases, while the Bayesian model is trained on labeled examples of phishing and legitimate text. When the user clicks "Scan Emails," the extension checks each email in Gmail's inbox. If it matches known keywords or the Bayesian classifier predicts a high probability of phishing (≥ 70%), the entire row is highlighted. This hybrid approach increases accuracy and reduces false positives by combining deterministic rules with adaptive probability-based logic.

🔁 1. Trainable Bayesian Filtering (with chrome.storage)

✅ Goal:

  • Allow the model to learn from user-labeled examples

  • Store spam/ham training data in Chrome’s local storage

  • Rebuild the classifier on every scan using saved data

📦 Update content.js — Part 1: Storage + Training Logic

🔁 Replace the classifier setup with this version:

javascript
let classifier = new NaiveBayes();

function loadTrainingData(callback) {
    chrome.storage.local.get(["spamTrain", "hamTrain"], (data) => {
        const spamExamples = data.spamTrain || [];
        const hamExamples = data.hamTrain || [];

        spamExamples.forEach(text => classifier.train(text, "spam"));
        hamExamples.forEach(text => classifier.train(text, "ham"));

        console.log(`Trained on ${spamExamples.length} spam + ${hamExamples.length} ham examples.`);
        callback();
    });
}

function saveTrainingData(text, label) {
    const key = label === "spam" ? "spamTrain" : "hamTrain";

    chrome.storage.local.get([key], (data) => {
        const updated = [...(data[key] || []), text];
        chrome.storage.local.set({ [key]: updated }, () => {
            console.log(`Saved new ${label} training example.`);
        });
    });
}

📦 Add Feedback Buttons on Each Highlighted Email

Inside your loop in scanGmailInbox(), after highlighting the row:

javascript
if (matchedKeyword || isPhishy) {
    const triggeredBy = matchedKeyword && isPhishy
        ? "Rule-based + Bayesian"
        : matchedKeyword
        ? "Rule-based"
        : "Bayesian";

    console.log(`Phishing detected: ${triggeredBy} | Prob=${phishingProb.toFixed(2)}`);
    highlightEmailRow(row);

    // Attach training buttons
    const feedbackDiv = document.createElement("div");
    feedbackDiv.innerHTML = `
        <button class="train-spam-btn">Mark as Spam</button>
        <button class="train-ham-btn">Mark as Safe</button>
    `;
    feedbackDiv.className = "train-feedback";
    row.appendChild(feedbackDiv);

    feedbackDiv.querySelector(".train-spam-btn").onclick = () => {
        saveTrainingData(row.innerText, "spam");
        feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as spam!</i>";
    };
    feedbackDiv.querySelector(".train-ham-btn").onclick = () => {
        saveTrainingData(row.innerText, "ham");
        feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as safe!</i>";
    };
}

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

let isHighlighting = false;

// ---------------------
// Bayesian Classifier
// ---------------------
class NaiveBayes {
    constructor() {
        this.spam = {};
        this.ham = {};
        this.spamCount = 0;
        this.hamCount = 0;
    }

    train(text, label) {
        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        const dict = label === "spam" ? this.spam : this.ham;
        if (label === "spam") this.spamCount++;
        else this.hamCount++;

        words.forEach(word => {
            dict[word] = (dict[word] || 0) + 1;
        });
    }

    predict(text) {
        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount));
        let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount));

        words.forEach(word => {
            spamScore += Math.log((this.spam[word] || 1) / this.spamCount);
            hamScore += Math.log((this.ham[word] || 1) / this.hamCount);
        });

        const spamProb = 1 / (1 + Math.exp(hamScore - spamScore));
        return spamProb;
    }
}

let classifier = new NaiveBayes();

// ---------------------
// Load/Save Training Data
// ---------------------
function loadTrainingData(callback) {
    chrome.storage.local.get(["spamTrain", "hamTrain"], (data) => {
        const spamExamples = data.spamTrain || [];
        const hamExamples = data.hamTrain || [];

        spamExamples.forEach(text => classifier.train(text, "spam"));
        hamExamples.forEach(text => classifier.train(text, "ham"));

        console.log(`Trained on ${spamExamples.length} spam and ${hamExamples.length} ham.`);
        callback();
    });
}

function saveTrainingData(text, label) {
    const key = label === "spam" ? "spamTrain" : "hamTrain";

    chrome.storage.local.get([key], (data) => {
        const updated = [...(data[key] || []), text];
        chrome.storage.local.set({ [key]: updated }, () => {
            console.log(`Saved new ${label} training example.`);
        });
    });
}

// ---------------------
// Email Highlighting
// ---------------------
function highlightEmailRow(row) {
    row.classList.add("phishing-alert");
}

function removeHighlights() {
    let highlightedRows = document.querySelectorAll(".phishing-alert");
    highlightedRows.forEach(row => row.classList.remove("phishing-alert"));
}

// ---------------------
// Inbox Scanner
// ---------------------
function scanGmailInbox() {
    if (isHighlighting) {
        console.log("Removing highlights...");
        removeHighlights();
        isHighlighting = false;
        return;
    }

    console.log("Scanning Gmail inbox for phishing threats...");

    const emailRows = document.querySelectorAll("tr");

    emailRows.forEach((row) => {
        if (!row || row.classList.contains("phishing-alert")) return;

        const emailText = row.innerText.toLowerCase();

        const matchedKeyword = phishingKeywords.some(kw => emailText.includes(kw));
        const phishingProb = classifier.predict(emailText);
        const isPhishy = phishingProb >= 0.7;

        if (matchedKeyword || isPhishy) {
            const triggeredBy = matchedKeyword && isPhishy
                ? "Rule-based + Bayesian"
                : matchedKeyword
                ? "Rule-based"
                : "Bayesian";

            console.log(`Phishing detected: ${triggeredBy} | Prob=${phishingProb.toFixed(2)}`);
            highlightEmailRow(row);

            // 📊 Display score
            const scoreDisplay = document.createElement("div");
            scoreDisplay.className = "phishing-score";
            scoreDisplay.textContent = `⚠️ Score: ${(phishingProb * 100).toFixed(1)}%`;
            row.appendChild(scoreDisplay);

            // 🔁 Training Buttons
            const feedbackDiv = document.createElement("div");
            feedbackDiv.innerHTML = `
                <button class="train-spam-btn">Mark as Spam</button>
                <button class="train-ham-btn">Mark as Safe</button>
            `;
            feedbackDiv.className = "train-feedback";
            row.appendChild(feedbackDiv);

            feedbackDiv.querySelector(".train-spam-btn").onclick = () => {
                saveTrainingData(row.innerText, "spam");
                feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as spam!</i>";
            };

            feedbackDiv.querySelector(".train-ham-btn").onclick = () => {
                saveTrainingData(row.innerText, "ham");
                feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as safe!</i>";
            };
        }
    });

    isHighlighting = true;
}

You said:
ChatGPT said:

Thanks for the screenshot — it confirms almost everything’s working, except for one thing:

⚠️ Issue: ⚠️ Score: NaN%

This means the Bayesian classifier is returning NaN (Not a Number) for the spam probability.

✅ What’s Causing It

The NaiveBayes.predict() method is trying to compute:

js
Math.log(this.spamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount))

If spamCount + hamCount = 0, it tries to divide by zero — this happens if there are no training examples yet (i.e., no calls to classifier.train()).

✅ How to Fix It

Update your predict() method to safely handle this case:

🔁 Replace this part in the NaiveBayes class:

js
predict(text) {
    const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
    let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount));
    let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / (this.spamCount + this.hamCount));

✅ With this safe check:

js
predict(text) {
    const total = this.spamCount + this.hamCount;
    if (total === 0) return 0.5; // neutral if no training data

    const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
    let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / total);
    let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / total);

📌 Why This Works

By defaulting to a probability of 0.5 when untrained, you avoid crashing and display:

txt
⚠️ Score: 50.0%

Until training examples are added via:

  • Mark as Spam

  • Mark as Safe

✅ After Fixing

  1. Reload your extension

  2. Open Gmail

  3. Click Scan Emails

  4. If no prior training exists, rows will show ⚠️ Score: 50.0%

  5. Once you train a few examples, future rows will show accurate percentages again

ChatGPT said:

Here’s your fully updated content.js code with the fix for the NaN% issue in the Bayesian classifier:

✅ Updated content.js (With Safe Bayesian Prediction)

javascript
const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",
    "bank account",
    "security alert",
    "confirm here"
];

let isHighlighting = false;

class NaiveBayes {
    constructor() {
        this.spam = {};
        this.ham = {};
        this.spamCount = 0;
        this.hamCount = 0;
    }

    train(text, label) {
        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        const dict = label === "spam" ? this.spam : this.ham;
        if (label === "spam") this.spamCount++;
        else this.hamCount++;

        words.forEach(word => {
            dict[word] = (dict[word] || 0) + 1;
        });
    }

    predict(text) {
        const total = this.spamCount + this.hamCount;
        if (total === 0) return 0.5; // Prevent NaN: return neutral score

        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / total);
        let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / total);

        words.forEach(word => {
            spamScore += Math.log((this.spam[word] || 1) / this.spamCount);
            hamScore += Math.log((this.ham[word] || 1) / this.hamCount);
        });

        const spamProb = 1 / (1 + Math.exp(hamScore - spamScore));
        return spamProb;
    }
}

let classifier = new NaiveBayes();

function loadTrainingData(callback) {
    chrome.storage.local.get(["spamTrain", "hamTrain"], (data) => {
        const spamExamples = data.spamTrain || [];
        const hamExamples = data.hamTrain || [];

        spamExamples.forEach(text => classifier.train(text, "spam"));
        hamExamples.forEach(text => classifier.train(text, "ham"));

        console.log(`Trained on ${spamExamples.length} spam and ${hamExamples.length} ham.`);
        callback();
    });
}

function saveTrainingData(text, label) {
    const key = label === "spam" ? "spamTrain" : "hamTrain";

    chrome.storage.local.get([key], (data) => {
        const updated = [...(data[key] || []), text];
        chrome.storage.local.set({ [key]: updated }, () => {
            console.log(`Saved new ${label} training example.`);
        });
    });
}

function highlightEmailRow(row) {
    row.classList.add("phishing-alert");
}

function removeHighlights() {
    let highlightedRows = document.querySelectorAll(".phishing-alert");
    highlightedRows.forEach(row => row.classList.remove("phishing-alert"));
}

function scanGmailInbox() {
    if (isHighlighting) {
        console.log("Removing highlights...");
        removeHighlights();
        isHighlighting = false;
        return;
    }

    console.log("Scanning Gmail inbox for phishing threats...");

    const emailRows = document.querySelectorAll("tr");

    emailRows.forEach((row) => {
        if (!row || row.classList.contains("phishing-alert")) return;

        const emailText = row.innerText.toLowerCase();

        const matchedKeyword = phishingKeywords.some(kw => emailText.includes(kw));
        const phishingProb = classifier.predict(emailText);
        const isPhishy = phishingProb >= 0.7;

        if (matchedKeyword || isPhishy) {
            const triggeredBy = matchedKeyword && isPhishy
                ? "Rule-based + Bayesian"
                : matchedKeyword
                ? "Rule-based"
                : "Bayesian";

            console.log(`Phishing detected: ${triggeredBy} | Prob=${phishingProb.toFixed(2)}`);
            highlightEmailRow(row);

            // 📊 Display score
            const scoreDisplay = document.createElement("div");
            scoreDisplay.className = "phishing-score";
            scoreDisplay.textContent = `⚠️ Score: ${(phishingProb * 100).toFixed(1)}%`;
            row.appendChild(scoreDisplay);

            // 🔁 Feedback buttons
            const feedbackDiv = document.createElement("div");
            feedbackDiv.innerHTML = `
                <button class="train-spam-btn">Mark as Spam</button>
                <button class="train-ham-btn">Mark as Safe</button>
            `;
            feedbackDiv.className = "train-feedback";
            row.appendChild(feedbackDiv);

            feedbackDiv.querySelector(".train-spam-btn").onclick = () => {
                saveTrainingData(row.innerText, "spam");
                feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as spam!</i>";
            };

            feedbackDiv.querySelector(".train-ham-btn").onclick = () => {
                saveTrainingData(row.innerText, "ham");
                feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as safe!</i>";
            };
        }
    });

    isHighlighting = true;
}

function injectStyles() {
    const style = document.createElement("style");
    style.innerHTML = `
        .phishing-alert {
            background-color: #ffcccc !important;
            font-weight: bold !important;
        }
        .phishing-score {
            font-size: 12px;
            color: #990000;
            padding: 2px;
            margin-top: 3px;
        }
        .train-feedback {
            margin-top: 5px;
            font-size: 12px;
        }
        .train-feedback button {
            background-color: #333;
            color: #fff;
            border: none;
            padding: 3px 6px;
            margin: 2px;
            font-size: 12px;
            border-radius: 4px;
            cursor: pointer;
        }
        .train-feedback button:hover {
            background-color: #555;
        }
    `;
    document.head.appendChild(style);
}

chrome.runtime.onMessage.addListener((message, sender, sendResponse) => {
    if (message.action === "scanEmails") {
        classifier = new NaiveBayes(); // reset
        loadTrainingData(scanGmailInbox);
        sendResponse({ status: isHighlighting ? "Highlighting enabled" : "Highlighting disabled" });
    }
});

injectStyles();

javascript
predict(text) {
    const total = this.spamCount + this.hamCount;
    if (total === 0) return 0.5;

    const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
    let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / total);
    let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / total);

    words.forEach(word => {
        spamScore += Math.log((this.spam[word] || 1) / this.spamCount);
        hamScore += Math.log((this.ham[word] || 1) / this.hamCount);
    });

    return 1 / (1 + Math.exp(hamScore - spamScore));
}

const phishingKeywords = [
    "urgent",
    "verify your account",
    "password reset",
    "suspicious activity",
    "update your details",
    "click here",
    "confirm now",
    "free gift",

class NaiveBayes {
    constructor() {
        this.spam = {};
        this.ham = {};
        this.spamCount = 0;
        this.hamCount = 0;
    }

    train(text, label) {
        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        const dict = label === "spam" ? this.spam : this.ham;
        if (label === "spam") this.spamCount++;
        else this.hamCount++;

        words.forEach(word => {
            dict[word] = (dict[word] || 0) + 1;
        });
    }

    predict(text) {
        const total = this.spamCount + this.hamCount;
        if (total === 0) return 0.5; // Safe fallback to avoid NaN%

        const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/).filter(Boolean);
        let spamScore = Math.log(this.spamCount / total);
        let hamScore = Math.log(this.hamCount / total);

        words.forEach(word => {
            spamScore += Math.log((this.spam[word] || 1) / this.spamCount);
            hamScore += Math.log((this.ham[word] || 1) / this.hamCount);
        });

        return 1 / (1 + Math.exp(hamScore - spamScore));
    }
}

function loadTrainingData(callback) {

                feedbackDiv.innerHTML = "<i>Saved as spam!</i>";

            };
        }

}

You said:
Explain the code in under a paragraph, answering the question: "How'd you get it to do percentage for spam I was under the impression that bayes is a binary decision"
ChatGPT said:

Great question! While Naive Bayes is often used for binary classification (spam vs. not spam), it actually works by calculating the probability that a message belongs to each class based on word frequency. In this extension, I used the formula 1 / (1 + e^(hamScore - spamScore)) to convert the log scores into a percentage likelihood that a message is spam. So instead of just saying “this is spam,” the classifier gives a confidence score (e.g., 84.7%), which we display in the UI. This allows for more nuanced decisions and better user feedback.

You said:
So then how does the Baysian filtering work
ChatGPT said:

Great question — let’s break it down in a simple, clear way:

🧠 How Bayesian Filtering Works in the Extension

  1. Training Phase:
    When you mark an email as "Spam" or "Safe," the extension stores the words in that email as examples of either phishing (spam) or legit (ham). It builds two word maps:

    • spam = { word: count }

    • ham = { word: count }

  2. Prediction Phase:
    When scanning emails, the extension:

    • Breaks the email text into words.

    • Looks at how often each word appeared in spam vs. ham training data.

    • Calculates two scores:

      • Spam score (likelihood the words match spam)

      • Ham score (likelihood the words match legit)

    • It then applies the formula:

      ini
      probability = 1 / (1 + e^(hamScore - spamScore))

      This turns the two scores into a probability between 0 and 1 (e.g., 0.83 = 83% spam).

  3. Decision:
    If the spam probability is ≥ 0.7 (70%), it flags the email as phishing. This threshold can be tuned.

✨ Why It’s Useful

Unlike pure keyword matching, Bayesian filtering adapts to how phishing evolves. Even if new phishing emails don’t match exact keywords, the classifier can detect patterns in word usage that look spammy based on past training.

Would you like a visual diagram or code flow explanation next?

Did you set up an API while combining the Rule-based and Baysian filtering?
ChatGPT said:

Nope — there’s no external API involved in combining the rule-based and Bayesian filtering in your extension. Everything is handled entirely locally within the browser using JavaScript.

🔍 How It Works Without an API

✅ Rule-Based Filtering

  • Uses a local array of suspicious keywords (e.g., "verify your account", "free gift").

  • Scans Gmail content directly from the DOM.

  • If a keyword matches → flags the email.

✅ Bayesian Filtering

  • A lightweight Naive Bayes classifier is written from scratch in JavaScript.

  • Training data (spam/ham examples) is saved to chrome.storage.local.

  • No cloud model, no server calls.

  • All predictions and training happen in the content script, on-device.

✅ Benefits of This Approach

  • 💡 Offline: Works even without internet.

  • 🔐 Private: User email content is never sent anywhere.

  • ⚡ Fast: All detection logic runs in-memory on the page.

  • 🔧 Customizable: Users can train their own spam/ham filters locally.

If you'd like, I can help you connect it to an API later (e.g., for remote training, backup, or shared phishing reports). But right now, it’s 100% self-contained and API-free.

ChatGPT said:

Awesome, Herik — let’s walk through how to integrate your real Multinomial Naive Bayes spam model into the Chrome extension using the classifier_model.json we just built.

✅ Step-by-Step: Add Real Bayesian Filtering (Fully Offline)

✅ Step 1: Add These Files to Your Extension Folder

✔️ Place these in your Chrome extension directory:

  • ✅ classifier_model.json ← Download it here

  • ✅ bayes_classifier.js ← will generate below

  • ✅ Already have vectorizer.vocabulary_? Let me know if you need that too

✅ Step 2: Add JavaScript Classifier Logic

Create a new file:
📄 bayes_classifier.js

Paste this code into it:

js
// Load classifier model
let NB_MODEL = null;

async function loadNaiveBayesModel() {
    const response = await fetch(chrome.runtime.getURL("classifier_model.json"));
    NB_MODEL = await response.json();
}

// Tokenize and count word frequencies
function getWordCounts(text, vocabulary) {
    const counts = new Array(vocabulary.length).fill(0);
    const words = text.toLowerCase().split(/\W+/);
    for (const word of words) {
        const idx = vocabulary.indexOf(word);
        if (idx !== -1) {
            counts[idx]++;
        }
    }
    return counts;
}

// Run prediction using MultinomialNB math
function predictSpamProbability(text, vocabulary) {
    if (!NB_MODEL) return 0.5; // fallback

    const wordCounts = getWordCounts(text, vocabulary);
    const { feature_log_prob, class_log_prior } = NB_MODEL;

    let scores = class_log_prior.map((prior, clsIdx) => {
        return prior + wordCounts.reduce((sum, count, wordIdx) => {
            return sum + count * feature_log_prob[clsIdx][wordIdx];
        }, 0);
    });

    // Softmax to turn log scores into probability
    const maxScore = Math.max(...scores);
    const expScores = scores.map(s => Math.exp(s - maxScore));
    const total = expScores.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0);
    const probs = expScores.map(s => s / total);

    return probs[1]; // index 1 = spam probability
}

✅ Step 3: Update manifest.json

Make sure it includes:

json
"web_accessible_resources": [
  {
    "resources": ["classifier_model.json"],
    "matches": ["<all_urls>"]
  }
],
"content_scripts": [
  {
    "matches": ["https://mail.google.com/*"],
    "js": ["bayes_classifier.js", "content.js"]
  }
